On Sun, Jan 18, 2026 at 10:12â€¯PM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
As Gregor and Rachel areÂ catching their breath after their brush with the "Dead Godâ€™s exhalation," Strahd von Zarovich steps forward. He does not offer a hand to help them. Instead, he looks at them with the cold, clinical interest of a scientist watching insects in a jar.

Strahd produces a small, luminescent spark from his cloakâ€”a glede, pulsing with an inner heat. As he holds it toward the Wall, the fog seems to curl in on itself extending tendrils of wisping misting laced with lightning.

With the sound of cracking ice, the vapor hardens. Strahd opens his palm to reveal four small gemstones, no larger than a fingernail.

  • For Rachel: A Silver Gemstone. It feels oddly warm, smelling faintly of cinnamon and old wood. (Grants the ability to cast Misty Step once by crushing it).

  • For Gregor: A Gray Gemstone. It pulses with a frantic, violet light, as if trying to recall the infinite library it was stolen from. (Grants the ability to cast Locate Object once by crushing it).

  • For Artur, Molock, and Francis: Three stones one silver, two gray remain in his palm. Though you did not enter, Strahd offers them with a mocking tilt of his head. "A pity to leave a wager unfinished. Take them. Consider them a dowry for the 'peace' you hope to find."

Strahd mounts Beucephalus, the Nightmareâ€™s hooves igniting with a sickly flame. He reaches into his heavy cloak and produces two final items, with a wave of his hand hovering gently in the air in front of him.

Strahd points to the hovering item:Â 
â€œIt is said that the god who died here, though its name is lost to time, left several relics behind. This is one of them.Â I give to you without let or lienÂ The Twilight Crest."

He gestures to the second item; aÂ thick envelope sealed with black wax.

"My chamberlain has grown weary of searching for you in the mud of the woods," Strahd remarks. "I extend to you a formal invitation to dine at my table.Â  I expect your attendance at dusk on the night of the moon's last light, in 5 days' time Â My carriage will be waiting at theÂ crossroads of Ravenloft, beyond the western gate."

With a flare of his cloak and a crack of dry thunder, the Count and his steed vanish.

On Sun, Jan 18, 2026 at 7:15â€¯PM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
Strahd tilts his head slightly, his eyes never leaving yours:
"You forget where you stand. Every stone, every leaf, and every wisp of fog is an extension of my reach. I may not see the fleeting colors of your heart's desire, but I see the silhouette they leave behind. One does not need to see the flame to know the shape of the moth's shadow upon the tent. I honor my word to the letter, as I expect of all in my domain."

And thank you ğŸ¥³Â

Artur stands firm beside Francis and does not enter the mists.

On Tue, Jan 13, 2026, 12:06â€¯PM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
You all watch as after Gregor stumble out ... Rachel steps in.

She is gone for barely more than a long breath, but as she emerges you see her eyes shining. Perhaps tears, or just the chill air of Barovia you cannot be certain.

Strahd watches you emerge, noting the emotion you display. He doesn't mock you as he did Gregor; instead, he looks at you with a strange, predatory curiosity.

"You carry the scent of a peaceful hearth, little artist. Most who enter the Wall see power or gold; you saw a home that no longer exists. A dangerous thing, to be anchored by love in a place that feeds on grief. I wonder... will that anchor keep you steady, or will it be the weight that finally pulls you under?"



On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 11:05â€¯AM Edward Baird <edward.r.baird@gmail.com> wrote:

On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 10:21â€¯AM Roland Zeuge <roland.zeuge@gmail.com> wrote:

On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 4:07â€¯PM Edward Baird <edward.r.baird@gmail.com> wrote:
Gregor staggers out of the mist... drunk?

And bleeding. Definitely bleeding; the stuff racing down his nose like a contest to escape whatever lies within.

He staggers uncontrollably, capers like a madman, cleaves his arms tightly to his chest with tears streaming down his face. something halfway between a sob and a cheer ripping from his throat as he stumbles to the ground before the party, kicking and agouging in the mud and the blood and the beer. Beer?

He jerks suddenly upright, still on his knees, blood and mud whipping away as he straightens ramrod; wild eyes locking fixedly on Morlock,Â 

His mouth opens, at first a squeek... then a roar, "YOU!!!!"

"ASK ME THE SECRET OF THE WEAVE OF MAKING GOODBERRY JUICE!!!!!"


On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 9:52â€¯AM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
You all watch as Gregor shuffles toward the wall, somehow faster or more driven toward it than anyone else in the party. (or the first to write an email response, who knows!?)

He is gone for only a few seconds. He lunges out of the fog, tumbling into the mud of Yester Hill with his arms wrapped tightly around... nothing.

His nose is bleeding slowly, and can't be staunched. (It will leak slowly for the next 1 hour of in game time)

Strahd watches Gregor tumble into the mud, clutching at the air.Â  He lets out a short, sharp bark of genuine amusement.

"A thief to the last, Sir Gregor? You tried to carry the sun out in a bucket. Many have tried to loot the Wall; few have the spirit to actually try and wrestle a god's memory into the mud. I admire the audacity, if not the results."

You will each have to enter alone, and what you see will be yours alone.

On Sat, Jan 10, 2026 at 9:11â€¯AM Adam Seefried <aseefried@gmail.com> wrote:

On Sat, Jan 10, 2026, 3:04â€¯AM Edward Baird <edward.r.baird@gmail.com> wrote:

â€œLetâ€™s see. a Towering White wall of mist; White wall of mist blasting up into the heavens and beyond; held within is the risk of becoming Lost, stuck for generations in search of knowledge and power and Dreaming of escape?Â  And for that small inconvenience, I get to keepâ€¦ an evaporating shard of mist,â€Â 


Gregorâ€™s grin is all teeth and bad judgment; as he he exhales sharply and tugs at his beard..


â€œWerewolvesâ€™ll no doubt be within too if thereâ€™s an impenetrable castle. Next youâ€™ll probably be promising me the opportunity to sit down for a tea party with the Fair Folk, along with lions, tigers, dragons and bloody scarecrows.â€


The toothy grin flashes wider still, â€œI do like tea. You shouldnâ€™t threaten me such a good time /and/ a meal! Of course Iâ€™m in!!â€


â€œBesides, I can hardly turn down an invitation, nor not be Accepted after a speech like that. You just said yourself thereâ€™s probably no way to be out.â€


The old man glances Skyward, begins to relieve himself of his clothes, before suddenlyÂ  stopping with a glanceÂ  at the others


An awkward cough later, Gregor plucks a loose thread his cloak, tossing the white thread aside into the grass and straightens his belt, mutters more to himself than the others, â€œerr, right. Leaving most of the clothes on.. I suppose..â€Â 


He glances about the party a final time, andÂ  immediately Harrumphs at them, â€œJust you wait and watch my greatest desire turn out to be purifying some witch at the stake when itâ€™s all said and done. Ahh well, Best head to it then ; I doubt I could weave in any more shite this evening if I tried!.â€


Gregor takes up his cane to prepare to enter the mists, harrumphing obnoxiously at the others all the while.


- Edward

On Sat, Jan 10, 2026 at 1:42â€¯AM Roland Zeuge <roland.zeuge@gmail.com> wrote:

On Sat, Jan 10, 2026 at 7:09â€¯AM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:

The air at the foot of Yester Hill is different. The scent of pine and ozone from the ritual has been replaced by a cloying, silver dampness that tastes of old copper and ancient dust. Ahead of you, the world simply... ends.

A shadowed wall of impenetrable fog looms above the earth here, stretching forth to meet the heavens far above. It is not a mist that moves with the wind; it is a solid, silent presence. As you stand before it, strange shapes and silhouettes drift through its depthsâ€”ghosts of things that never wereâ€”and distant voices whisper just out of earshot, calling your names in a language you almost understand.

Standing thirty feet away from his nightmare, Beucephalus, Strahd von Zarovich rises from a kneeling position as you approach. He pockets something small and luminescent within his cloak, a thin smile playing on his lips.

"Congratulations," he says, his voice cutting through the damp silence. "You played my little game with surprising competence. I trust Ludmilla's humiliation will serve as a lasting lesson for her."

He gestures to the towering bank of fog behind him.

"The ancestors of the Forest Folk believed this to be the corpse of an ancient god, whose last exhalation of divinity produced this mist. They called it the Whispering Wall. It is said that for those with the courage to enter as pilgrims, the Wall offers a vision of one's deepest desires."

He pauses, his eyes reflecting the silver gray of the mist.

"It is a powerful thing, to know oneself and one's desires. And yet dangerous, as well. I have walked its depths myself. I have seen the white fortress of my youth, the bells of my home ringing through the fog. It is... enticing."

Strahd offers you a final challenge before he grants you the rewards of your victory:

  1. The Pilgrimage: You must step into the Wall and face what you truly want. Strahd promises not to look; your desires are yours alone.

  2. The Risk: Many become lost, too entranced by the illusions to ever leave.

  3. The Choice: To return, you must leave under your own power. The way back comes but once.

  4. The Reward: Those who return safely will receive a "shard of the power of the Wall itself."

He watches you now, a taunting glint in his eye, waiting to see if you have the strength of will to face yourselves, or if you are merely "lesser men" doomed to trade your lives for dreams.

A simple question for each of you... Do you step into the mist?

Remember his warning:Â The way back comes but once.

You all watch as Gregor shuffles toward the wall, somehow faster or more driven toward it than anyone else in the party. (or the first to write an email response, who knows!?)

He is gone for only a few seconds. He lunges out of the fog, tumbling into the mud of Yester Hill with his arms wrapped tightly around... nothing.

His nose is bleeding slowly, and can't be staunched. (It will leak slowly for the next 1 hour of in game time)

Strahd watches Gregor tumble into the mud, clutching at the air.Â  He lets out a short, sharp bark of genuine amusement.

"A thief to the last, Sir Gregor? You tried to carry the sun out in a bucket. Many have tried to loot the Wall; few have the spirit to actually try and wrestle a god's memory into the mud. I admire the audacity, if not the results."

â€œWerewolvesâ€™ll no doubt be within too if thereâ€™s an impenetrable castle. Next youâ€™ll probably be promising me the opportunity to sit down for a tea party with the Fair Folk, along with lions, tigers, dragons and bloody scarecrows.â€

Gregor takes up his cane to prepare to enter the mists, harrumphing obnoxiously at the others all the while.

On Sat, Jan 10, 2026 at 1:42â€¯AM Roland Zeuge <roland.zeuge@gmail.com> wrote:

On Sat, Jan 10, 2026 at 7:09â€¯AM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:

The air at the foot of Yester Hill is different. The scent of pine and ozone from the ritual has been replaced by a cloying, silver dampness that tastes of old copper and ancient dust. Ahead of you, the world simply... ends.

A shadowed wall of impenetrable fog looms above the earth here, stretching forth to meet the heavens far above. It is not a mist that moves with the wind; it is a solid, silent presence. As you stand before it, strange shapes and silhouettes drift through its depthsâ€”ghosts of things that never wereâ€”and distant voices whisper just out of earshot, calling your names in a language you almost understand.

Standing thirty feet away from his nightmare, Beucephalus, Strahd von Zarovich rises from a kneeling position as you approach. He pockets something small and luminescent within his cloak, a thin smile playing on his lips.

"Congratulations," he says, his voice cutting through the damp silence. "You played my little game with surprising competence. I trust Ludmilla's humiliation will serve as a lasting lesson for her."

He gestures to the towering bank of fog behind him.

"The ancestors of the Forest Folk believed this to be the corpse of an ancient god, whose last exhalation of divinity produced this mist. They called it the Whispering Wall. It is said that for those with the courage to enter as pilgrims, the Wall offers a vision of one's deepest desires."

He pauses, his eyes reflecting the silver gray of the mist.

"It is a powerful thing, to know oneself and one's desires. And yet dangerous, as well. I have walked its depths myself. I have seen the white fortress of my youth, the bells of my home ringing through the fog. It is... enticing."

Strahd offers you a final challenge before he grants you the rewards of your victory:

  1. The Pilgrimage: You must step into the Wall and face what you truly want. Strahd promises not to look; your desires are yours alone.

  2. The Risk: Many become lost, too entranced by the illusions to ever leave.

  3. The Choice: To return, you must leave under your own power. The way back comes but once.

  4. The Reward: Those who return safely will receive a "shard of the power of the Wall itself."

He watches you now, a taunting glint in his eye, waiting to see if you have the strength of will to face yourselves, or if you are merely "lesser men" doomed to trade your lives for dreams.

A simple question for each of you... Do you step into the mist?

Remember his warning:Â The way back comes but once.

On Sun, Jan 18, 2026 at 10:12â€¯PM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
As Gregor and Rachel areÂ catching their breath after their brush with the "Dead Godâ€™s exhalation," Strahd von Zarovich steps forward. He does not offer a hand to help them. Instead, he looks at them with the cold, clinical interest of a scientist watching insects in a jar.

Strahd produces a small, luminescent spark from his cloakâ€”a glede, pulsing with an inner heat. As he holds it toward the Wall, the fog seems to curl in on itself extending tendrils of wisping misting laced with lightning.

With the sound of cracking ice, the vapor hardens. Strahd opens his palm to reveal four small gemstones, no larger than a fingernail.

  • For Rachel: A Silver Gemstone. It feels oddly warm, smelling faintly of cinnamon and old wood. (Grants the ability to cast Misty Step once by crushing it).

  • For Gregor: A Gray Gemstone. It pulses with a frantic, violet light, as if trying to recall the infinite library it was stolen from. (Grants the ability to cast Locate Object once by crushing it).

  • For Artur, Molock, and Francis: Three stones one silver, two gray remain in his palm. Though you did not enter, Strahd offers them with a mocking tilt of his head. "A pity to leave a wager unfinished. Take them. Consider them a dowry for the 'peace' you hope to find."

Strahd mounts Beucephalus, the Nightmareâ€™s hooves igniting with a sickly flame. He reaches into his heavy cloak and produces two final items, with a wave of his hand hovering gently in the air in front of him.

Strahd points to the hovering item:Â 
â€œIt is said that the god who died here, though its name is lost to time, left several relics behind. This is one of them.Â I give to you without let or lienÂ The Twilight Crest."

He gestures to the second item; aÂ thick envelope sealed with black wax.

"My chamberlain has grown weary of searching for you in the mud of the woods," Strahd remarks. "I extend to you a formal invitation to dine at my table.Â  I expect your attendance at dusk on the night of the moon's last light, in 5 days' time Â My carriage will be waiting at theÂ crossroads of Ravenloft, beyond the western gate."

With a flare of his cloak and a crack of dry thunder, the Count and his steed vanish.

I honor my word to the letter, as I expect of all in my domain."

On Tue, Jan 13, 2026, 12:06â€¯PM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
You all watch as after Gregor stumble out ... Rachel steps in.

She is gone for barely more than a long breath, but as she emerges you see her eyes shining. Perhaps tears, or just the chill air of Barovia you cannot be certain.

Strahd watches you emerge, noting the emotion you display. He doesn't mock you as he did Gregor; instead, he looks at you with a strange, predatory curiosity.

"You carry the scent of a peaceful hearth, little artist. Most who enter the Wall see power or gold; you saw a home that no longer exists. A dangerous thing, to be anchored by love in a place that feeds on grief. I wonder... will that anchor keep you steady, or will it be the weight that finally pulls you under?"

Gregor staggers out of the mist... drunk?

He staggers uncontrollably, capers like a madman, cleaves his arms tightly to his chest with tears streaming down his face. something halfway between a sob and a cheer ripping from his throat as he stumbles to the ground before the party, kicking and agouging in the mud and the blood and the beer. He jerks suddenly upright, still on his knees, blood and mud whipping away as he straightens ramrod; wild eyes locking fixedly on Morlock,Â 

His mouth opens, at first a squeek... then a roar, "YOU!!!!"

On Sat, Jan 10, 2026 at 7:09â€¯AM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:

The air at the foot of Yester Hill is different. The scent of pine and ozone from the ritual has been replaced by a cloying, silver dampness that tastes of old copper and ancient dust. Ahead of you, the world simply... ends.

A shadowed wall of impenetrable fog looms above the earth here, stretching forth to meet the heavens far above. It is not a mist that moves with the wind; it is a solid, silent presence. As you stand before it, strange shapes and silhouettes drift through its depthsâ€”ghosts of things that never wereâ€”and distant voices whisper just out of earshot, calling your names in a language you almost understand.

Standing thirty feet away from his nightmare, Beucephalus, Strahd von Zarovich rises from a kneeling position as you approach. He pockets something small and luminescent within his cloak, a thin smile playing on his lips.

"Congratulations," he says, his voice cutting through the damp silence. "You played my little game with surprising competence. I trust Ludmilla's humiliation will serve as a lasting lesson for her."

He gestures to the towering bank of fog behind him.

"The ancestors of the Forest Folk believed this to be the corpse of an ancient god, whose last exhalation of divinity produced this mist. They called it the Whispering Wall. It is said that for those with the courage to enter as pilgrims, the Wall offers a vision of one's deepest desires."

He pauses, his eyes reflecting the silver gray of the mist.

"It is a powerful thing, to know oneself and one's desires. And yet dangerous, as well. I have walked its depths myself. I have seen the white fortress of my youth, the bells of my home ringing through the fog. It is... enticing."

Strahd offers you a final challenge before he grants you the rewards of your victory:

  1. The Pilgrimage: You must step into the Wall and face what you truly want. Strahd promises not to look; your desires are yours alone.

  2. The Risk: Many become lost, too entranced by the illusions to ever leave.

  3. The Choice: To return, you must leave under your own power. The way back comes but once.

  4. The Reward: Those who return safely will receive a "shard of the power of the Wall itself."

He watches you now, a taunting glint in his eye, waiting to see if you have the strength of will to face yourselves, or if you are merely "lesser men" doomed to trade your lives for dreams.

A simple question for each of you... Do you step into the mist?

Remember his warning:Â The way back comes but once.

  • For Rachel: A Silver Gemstone. It feels oddly warm, smelling faintly of cinnamon and old wood. (Grants the ability to cast Misty Step once by crushing it).

  • For Gregor: A Gray Gemstone. It pulses with a frantic, violet light, as if trying to recall the infinite library it was stolen from. (Grants the ability to cast Locate Object once by crushing it).

  • For Artur, Molock, and Francis: Three stones one silver, two gray remain in his palm. Though you did not enter, Strahd offers them with a mocking tilt of his head. "A pity to leave a wager unfinished. Take them. Consider them a dowry for the 'peace' you hope to find."

Strahd mounts Beucephalus, the Nightmareâ€™s hooves igniting with a sickly flame. He reaches into his heavy cloak and produces two final items, with a wave of his hand hovering gently in the air in front of him.

Strahd points to the hovering item:Â 
â€œIt is said that the god who died here, though its name is lost to time, left several relics behind. This is one of them.Â I give to you without let or lienÂ The Twilight Crest."

He gestures to the second item; aÂ thick envelope sealed with black wax.

"My chamberlain has grown weary of searching for you in the mud of the woods," Strahd remarks. "I extend to you a formal invitation to dine at my table.Â  I expect your attendance at dusk on the night of the moon's last light, in 5 days' time Â My carriage will be waiting at theÂ crossroads of Ravenloft, beyond the western gate."

With a flare of his cloak and a crack of dry thunder, the Count and his steed vanish.

On Sun, Jan 18, 2026 at 7:15â€¯PM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
Strahd tilts his head slightly, his eyes never leaving yours:
"You forget where you stand. Every stone, every leaf, and every wisp of fog is an extension of my reach. I may not see the fleeting colors of your heart's desire, but I see the silhouette they leave behind. One does not need to see the flame to know the shape of the moth's shadow upon the tent. I honor my word to the letter, as I expect of all in my domain."

On Tue, Jan 13, 2026, 12:06â€¯PM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
You all watch as after Gregor stumble out ... Rachel steps in.

She is gone for barely more than a long breath, but as she emerges you see her eyes shining. Perhaps tears, or just the chill air of Barovia you cannot be certain.

Strahd watches you emerge, noting the emotion you display. He doesn't mock you as he did Gregor; instead, he looks at you with a strange, predatory curiosity.

"You carry the scent of a peaceful hearth, little artist. Most who enter the Wall see power or gold; you saw a home that no longer exists. A dangerous thing, to be anchored by love in a place that feeds on grief. I wonder... will that anchor keep you steady, or will it be the weight that finally pulls you under?"

On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 4:07â€¯PM Edward Baird <edward.r.baird@gmail.com> wrote:
Gregor staggers out of the mist... drunk?

And bleeding. Definitely bleeding; the stuff racing down his nose like a contest to escape whatever lies within.

He staggers uncontrollably, capers like a madman, cleaves his arms tightly to his chest with tears streaming down his face. something halfway between a sob and a cheer ripping from his throat as he stumbles to the ground before the party, kicking and agouging in the mud and the blood and the beer. Beer?

He jerks suddenly upright, still on his knees, blood and mud whipping away as he straightens ramrod; wild eyes locking fixedly on Morlock,Â 

His mouth opens, at first a squeek... then a roar, "YOU!!!!"

"ASK ME THE SECRET OF THE WEAVE OF MAKING GOODBERRY JUICE!!!!!"


On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 9:52â€¯AM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
You all watch as Gregor shuffles toward the wall, somehow faster or more driven toward it than anyone else in the party. (or the first to write an email response, who knows!?)

He is gone for only a few seconds. He lunges out of the fog, tumbling into the mud of Yester Hill with his arms wrapped tightly around... nothing.

His nose is bleeding slowly, and can't be staunched. (It will leak slowly for the next 1 hour of in game time)

Strahd watches Gregor tumble into the mud, clutching at the air.Â  He lets out a short, sharp bark of genuine amusement.

"A thief to the last, Sir Gregor? You tried to carry the sun out in a bucket. Many have tried to loot the Wall; few have the spirit to actually try and wrestle a god's memory into the mud. I admire the audacity, if not the results."

On Sat, Jan 10, 2026 at 7:09â€¯AM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:

The air at the foot of Yester Hill is different. The scent of pine and ozone from the ritual has been replaced by a cloying, silver dampness that tastes of old copper and ancient dust. Ahead of you, the world simply... ends.

A shadowed wall of impenetrable fog looms above the earth here, stretching forth to meet the heavens far above. It is not a mist that moves with the wind; it is a solid, silent presence. As you stand before it, strange shapes and silhouettes drift through its depthsâ€”ghosts of things that never wereâ€”and distant voices whisper just out of earshot, calling your names in a language you almost understand.

Standing thirty feet away from his nightmare, Beucephalus, Strahd von Zarovich rises from a kneeling position as you approach. He pockets something small and luminescent within his cloak, a thin smile playing on his lips.

"Congratulations," he says, his voice cutting through the damp silence. "You played my little game with surprising competence. I trust Ludmilla's humiliation will serve as a lasting lesson for her."

He gestures to the towering bank of fog behind him.

"The ancestors of the Forest Folk believed this to be the corpse of an ancient god, whose last exhalation of divinity produced this mist. They called it the Whispering Wall. It is said that for those with the courage to enter as pilgrims, the Wall offers a vision of one's deepest desires."

He pauses, his eyes reflecting the silver gray of the mist.

"It is a powerful thing, to know oneself and one's desires. And yet dangerous, as well. I have walked its depths myself. I have seen the white fortress of my youth, the bells of my home ringing through the fog. It is... enticing."

Strahd offers you a final challenge before he grants you the rewards of your victory:

  1. The Pilgrimage: You must step into the Wall and face what you truly want. Strahd promises not to look; your desires are yours alone.

  2. The Risk: Many become lost, too entranced by the illusions to ever leave.

  3. The Choice: To return, you must leave under your own power. The way back comes but once.

  4. The Reward: Those who return safely will receive a "shard of the power of the Wall itself."

He watches you now, a taunting glint in his eye, waiting to see if you have the strength of will to face yourselves, or if you are merely "lesser men" doomed to trade your lives for dreams.

A simple question for each of you... Do you step into the mist?

Remember his warning:Â The way back comes but once.

On Sun, Jan 18, 2026 at 10:12â€¯PM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
As Gregor and Rachel areÂ catching their breath after their brush with the "Dead Godâ€™s exhalation," Strahd von Zarovich steps forward. He does not offer a hand to help them. Instead, he looks at them with the cold, clinical interest of a scientist watching insects in a jar.

Strahd produces a small, luminescent spark from his cloakâ€”a glede, pulsing with an inner heat. As he holds it toward the Wall, the fog seems to curl in on itself extending tendrils of wisping misting laced with lightning.

With the sound of cracking ice, the vapor hardens. Strahd opens his palm to reveal four small gemstones, no larger than a fingernail.

  • For Rachel: A Silver Gemstone. It feels oddly warm, smelling faintly of cinnamon and old wood. (Grants the ability to cast Misty Step once by crushing it).

  • For Gregor: A Gray Gemstone. It pulses with a frantic, violet light, as if trying to recall the infinite library it was stolen from. (Grants the ability to cast Locate Object once by crushing it).

  • For Artur, Molock, and Francis: Three stones one silver, two gray remain in his palm. Though you did not enter, Strahd offers them with a mocking tilt of his head. "A pity to leave a wager unfinished. Take them. Consider them a dowry for the 'peace' you hope to find."

Strahd mounts Beucephalus, the Nightmareâ€™s hooves igniting with a sickly flame. He reaches into his heavy cloak and produces two final items, with a wave of his hand hovering gently in the air in front of him.

Strahd points to the hovering item:Â 
â€œIt is said that the god who died here, though its name is lost to time, left several relics behind. This is one of them.Â I give to you without let or lienÂ The Twilight Crest."

He gestures to the second item; aÂ thick envelope sealed with black wax.

"My chamberlain has grown weary of searching for you in the mud of the woods," Strahd remarks. "I extend to you a formal invitation to dine at my table.Â  I expect your attendance at dusk on the night of the moon's last light, in 5 days' time Â My carriage will be waiting at theÂ crossroads of Ravenloft, beyond the western gate."

With a flare of his cloak and a crack of dry thunder, the Count and his steed vanish.

On Sat, Jan 10, 2026 at 7:09â€¯AM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:

The air at the foot of Yester Hill is different. The scent of pine and ozone from the ritual has been replaced by a cloying, silver dampness that tastes of old copper and ancient dust. Ahead of you, the world simply... ends.

A shadowed wall of impenetrable fog looms above the earth here, stretching forth to meet the heavens far above. It is not a mist that moves with the wind; it is a solid, silent presence. As you stand before it, strange shapes and silhouettes drift through its depthsâ€”ghosts of things that never wereâ€”and distant voices whisper just out of earshot, calling your names in a language you almost understand.

Standing thirty feet away from his nightmare, Beucephalus, Strahd von Zarovich rises from a kneeling position as you approach. He pockets something small and luminescent within his cloak, a thin smile playing on his lips.

"Congratulations," he says, his voice cutting through the damp silence. "You played my little game with surprising competence. I trust Ludmilla's humiliation will serve as a lasting lesson for her."

He gestures to the towering bank of fog behind him.

"The ancestors of the Forest Folk believed this to be the corpse of an ancient god, whose last exhalation of divinity produced this mist. They called it the Whispering Wall. It is said that for those with the courage to enter as pilgrims, the Wall offers a vision of one's deepest desires."

He pauses, his eyes reflecting the silver gray of the mist.

"It is a powerful thing, to know oneself and one's desires. And yet dangerous, as well. I have walked its depths myself. I have seen the white fortress of my youth, the bells of my home ringing through the fog. It is... enticing."

Strahd offers you a final challenge before he grants you the rewards of your victory:

  1. The Pilgrimage: You must step into the Wall and face what you truly want. Strahd promises not to look; your desires are yours alone.

  2. The Risk: Many become lost, too entranced by the illusions to ever leave.

  3. The Choice: To return, you must leave under your own power. The way back comes but once.

  4. The Reward: Those who return safely will receive a "shard of the power of the Wall itself."

He watches you now, a taunting glint in his eye, waiting to see if you have the strength of will to face yourselves, or if you are merely "lesser men" doomed to trade your lives for dreams.

A simple question for each of you... Do you step into the mist?

Remember his warning:Â The way back comes but once.

On Sun, Jan 18, 2026 at 10:12â€¯PM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
As Gregor and Rachel areÂ catching their breath after their brush with the "Dead Godâ€™s exhalation," Strahd von Zarovich steps forward. He does not offer a hand to help them. Instead, he looks at them with the cold, clinical interest of a scientist watching insects in a jar.

Strahd produces a small, luminescent spark from his cloakâ€”a glede, pulsing with an inner heat. As he holds it toward the Wall, the fog seems to curl in on itself extending tendrils of wisping misting laced with lightning.

With the sound of cracking ice, the vapor hardens. Strahd opens his palm to reveal four small gemstones, no larger than a fingernail.

  • For Rachel: A Silver Gemstone. It feels oddly warm, smelling faintly of cinnamon and old wood. (Grants the ability to cast Misty Step once by crushing it).

  • For Gregor: A Gray Gemstone. It pulses with a frantic, violet light, as if trying to recall the infinite library it was stolen from. (Grants the ability to cast Locate Object once by crushing it).

  • For Artur, Molock, and Francis: Three stones one silver, two gray remain in his palm. Though you did not enter, Strahd offers them with a mocking tilt of his head. "A pity to leave a wager unfinished. Take them. Consider them a dowry for the 'peace' you hope to find."

Strahd mounts Beucephalus, the Nightmareâ€™s hooves igniting with a sickly flame. He reaches into his heavy cloak and produces two final items, with a wave of his hand hovering gently in the air in front of him.

Strahd points to the hovering item:Â 
â€œIt is said that the god who died here, though its name is lost to time, left several relics behind. This is one of them.Â I give to you without let or lienÂ The Twilight Crest."

He gestures to the second item; aÂ thick envelope sealed with black wax.

"My chamberlain has grown weary of searching for you in the mud of the woods," Strahd remarks. "I extend to you a formal invitation to dine at my table.Â  I expect your attendance at dusk on the night of the moon's last light, in 5 days' time Â My carriage will be waiting at theÂ crossroads of Ravenloft, beyond the western gate."

With a flare of his cloak and a crack of dry thunder, the Count and his steed vanish.

I honor my word to the letter, as I expect of all in my domain."

On Tue, Jan 13, 2026, 12:06â€¯PM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
You all watch as after Gregor stumble out ... Rachel steps in.

She is gone for barely more than a long breath, but as she emerges you see her eyes shining. Perhaps tears, or just the chill air of Barovia you cannot be certain.

Strahd watches you emerge, noting the emotion you display. He doesn't mock you as he did Gregor; instead, he looks at you with a strange, predatory curiosity.

"You carry the scent of a peaceful hearth, little artist. Most who enter the Wall see power or gold; you saw a home that no longer exists. A dangerous thing, to be anchored by love in a place that feeds on grief. I wonder... will that anchor keep you steady, or will it be the weight that finally pulls you under?"

On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 4:07â€¯PM Edward Baird <edward.r.baird@gmail.com> wrote:
Gregor staggers out of the mist... drunk?

And bleeding. Definitely bleeding; the stuff racing down his nose like a contest to escape whatever lies within.

He staggers uncontrollably, capers like a madman, cleaves his arms tightly to his chest with tears streaming down his face. something halfway between a sob and a cheer ripping from his throat as he stumbles to the ground before the party, kicking and agouging in the mud and the blood and the beer. Beer?

He jerks suddenly upright, still on his knees, blood and mud whipping away as he straightens ramrod; wild eyes locking fixedly on Morlock,Â 

His mouth opens, at first a squeek... then a roar, "YOU!!!!"

"ASK ME THE SECRET OF THE WEAVE OF MAKING GOODBERRY JUICE!!!!!"


On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 9:52â€¯AM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
You all watch as Gregor shuffles toward the wall, somehow faster or more driven toward it than anyone else in the party. (or the first to write an email response, who knows!?)

He is gone for only a few seconds. He lunges out of the fog, tumbling into the mud of Yester Hill with his arms wrapped tightly around... nothing.

His nose is bleeding slowly, and can't be staunched. (It will leak slowly for the next 1 hour of in game time)

Strahd watches Gregor tumble into the mud, clutching at the air.Â  He lets out a short, sharp bark of genuine amusement.

"A thief to the last, Sir Gregor? You tried to carry the sun out in a bucket. Many have tried to loot the Wall; few have the spirit to actually try and wrestle a god's memory into the mud. I admire the audacity, if not the results."

â€œWerewolvesâ€™ll no doubt be within too if thereâ€™s an impenetrable castle. Next youâ€™ll probably be promising me the opportunity to sit down for a tea party with the Fair Folk, along with lions, tigers, dragons and bloody scarecrows.â€


The toothy grin flashes wider still, â€œI do like tea. You shouldnâ€™t threaten me such a good time /and/ a meal! Of course Iâ€™m in!!â€


â€œBesides, I can hardly turn down an invitation, nor not be Accepted after a speech like that. You just said yourself thereâ€™s probably no way to be out.â€


The old man glances Skyward, begins to relieve himself of his clothes, before suddenlyÂ  stopping with a glanceÂ  at the others


An awkward cough later, Gregor plucks a loose thread his cloak, tossing the white thread aside into the grass and straightens his belt, mutters more to himself than the others, â€œerr, right. Leaving most of the clothes on.. I suppose..â€Â 


He glances about the party a final time, andÂ  immediately Harrumphs at them, â€œJust you wait and watch my greatest desire turn out to be purifying some witch at the stake when itâ€™s all said and done. Ahh well, Best head to it then ; I doubt I could weave in any more shite this evening if I tried!.â€


Gregor takes up his cane to prepare to enter the mists, harrumphing obnoxiously at the others all the while.

On Sat, Jan 10, 2026 at 1:42â€¯AM Roland Zeuge <roland.zeuge@gmail.com> wrote:

On Sat, Jan 10, 2026 at 7:09â€¯AM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:

The air at the foot of Yester Hill is different. The scent of pine and ozone from the ritual has been replaced by a cloying, silver dampness that tastes of old copper and ancient dust. Ahead of you, the world simply... ends.

A shadowed wall of impenetrable fog looms above the earth here, stretching forth to meet the heavens far above. It is not a mist that moves with the wind; it is a solid, silent presence. As you stand before it, strange shapes and silhouettes drift through its depthsâ€”ghosts of things that never wereâ€”and distant voices whisper just out of earshot, calling your names in a language you almost understand.

Standing thirty feet away from his nightmare, Beucephalus, Strahd von Zarovich rises from a kneeling position as you approach. He pockets something small and luminescent within his cloak, a thin smile playing on his lips.

"Congratulations," he says, his voice cutting through the damp silence. "You played my little game with surprising competence. I trust Ludmilla's humiliation will serve as a lasting lesson for her."

He gestures to the towering bank of fog behind him.

"The ancestors of the Forest Folk believed this to be the corpse of an ancient god, whose last exhalation of divinity produced this mist. They called it the Whispering Wall. It is said that for those with the courage to enter as pilgrims, the Wall offers a vision of one's deepest desires."

He pauses, his eyes reflecting the silver gray of the mist.

"It is a powerful thing, to know oneself and one's desires. And yet dangerous, as well. I have walked its depths myself. I have seen the white fortress of my youth, the bells of my home ringing through the fog. It is... enticing."

Strahd offers you a final challenge before he grants you the rewards of your victory:

  1. The Pilgrimage: You must step into the Wall and face what you truly want. Strahd promises not to look; your desires are yours alone.

  2. The Risk: Many become lost, too entranced by the illusions to ever leave.

  3. The Choice: To return, you must leave under your own power. The way back comes but once.

  4. The Reward: Those who return safely will receive a "shard of the power of the Wall itself."

He watches you now, a taunting glint in his eye, waiting to see if you have the strength of will to face yourselves, or if you are merely "lesser men" doomed to trade your lives for dreams.

A simple question for each of you... Do you step into the mist?

Remember his warning:Â The way back comes but once.

â€œWerewolvesâ€™ll no doubt be within too if thereâ€™s an impenetrable castle. Next youâ€™ll probably be promising me the opportunity to sit down for a tea party with the Fair Folk, along with lions, tigers, dragons and bloody scarecrows.â€


The toothy grin flashes wider still, â€œI do like tea. You shouldnâ€™t threaten me such a good time /and/ a meal! Of course Iâ€™m in!!â€


â€œBesides, I can hardly turn down an invitation, nor not be Accepted after a speech like that. You just said yourself thereâ€™s probably no way to be out.â€


The old man glances Skyward, begins to relieve himself of his clothes, before suddenlyÂ  stopping with a glanceÂ  at the others


An awkward cough later, Gregor plucks a loose thread his cloak, tossing the white thread aside into the grass and straightens his belt, mutters more to himself than the others, â€œerr, right. Leaving most of the clothes on.. I suppose..â€Â 


He glances about the party a final time, andÂ  immediately Harrumphs at them, â€œJust you wait and watch my greatest desire turn out to be purifying some witch at the stake when itâ€™s all said and done. Ahh well, Best head to it then ; I doubt I could weave in any more shite this evening if I tried!.â€


Gregor takes up his cane to prepare to enter the mists, harrumphing obnoxiously at the others all the while.

On Sat, Jan 10, 2026 at 1:42â€¯AM Roland Zeuge <roland.zeuge@gmail.com> wrote:
Does the Artist want to see dreams and visions?Â Â 
Does a Vampire go out at night?

Of course Rachel's in!

On Sat, Jan 10, 2026 at 7:09â€¯AM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:

The air at the foot of Yester Hill is different. The scent of pine and ozone from the ritual has been replaced by a cloying, silver dampness that tastes of old copper and ancient dust. Ahead of you, the world simply... ends.

A shadowed wall of impenetrable fog looms above the earth here, stretching forth to meet the heavens far above. It is not a mist that moves with the wind; it is a solid, silent presence. As you stand before it, strange shapes and silhouettes drift through its depthsâ€”ghosts of things that never wereâ€”and distant voices whisper just out of earshot, calling your names in a language you almost understand.

Standing thirty feet away from his nightmare, Beucephalus, Strahd von Zarovich rises from a kneeling position as you approach. He pockets something small and luminescent within his cloak, a thin smile playing on his lips.

"Congratulations," he says, his voice cutting through the damp silence. "You played my little game with surprising competence. I trust Ludmilla's humiliation will serve as a lasting lesson for her."

He gestures to the towering bank of fog behind him.

"The ancestors of the Forest Folk believed this to be the corpse of an ancient god, whose last exhalation of divinity produced this mist. They called it the Whispering Wall. It is said that for those with the courage to enter as pilgrims, the Wall offers a vision of one's deepest desires."

He pauses, his eyes reflecting the silver gray of the mist.

"It is a powerful thing, to know oneself and one's desires. And yet dangerous, as well. I have walked its depths myself. I have seen the white fortress of my youth, the bells of my home ringing through the fog. It is... enticing."

Strahd offers you a final challenge before he grants you the rewards of your victory:

  1. The Pilgrimage: You must step into the Wall and face what you truly want. Strahd promises not to look; your desires are yours alone.

  2. The Risk: Many become lost, too entranced by the illusions to ever leave.

  3. The Choice: To return, you must leave under your own power. The way back comes but once.

  4. The Reward: Those who return safely will receive a "shard of the power of the Wall itself."

He watches you now, a taunting glint in his eye, waiting to see if you have the strength of will to face yourselves, or if you are merely "lesser men" doomed to trade your lives for dreams.

A simple question for each of you... Do you step into the mist?

Remember his warning:Â The way back comes but once.

On Sun, Jan 18, 2026 at 10:12â€¯PM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
As Gregor and Rachel areÂ catching their breath after their brush with the "Dead Godâ€™s exhalation," Strahd von Zarovich steps forward. He does not offer a hand to help them. Instead, he looks at them with the cold, clinical interest of a scientist watching insects in a jar.

Strahd produces a small, luminescent spark from his cloakâ€”a glede, pulsing with an inner heat. As he holds it toward the Wall, the fog seems to curl in on itself extending tendrils of wisping misting laced with lightning.

With the sound of cracking ice, the vapor hardens. Strahd opens his palm to reveal four small gemstones, no larger than a fingernail.

  • For Rachel: A Silver Gemstone. It feels oddly warm, smelling faintly of cinnamon and old wood. (Grants the ability to cast Misty Step once by crushing it).

  • For Gregor: A Gray Gemstone. It pulses with a frantic, violet light, as if trying to recall the infinite library it was stolen from. (Grants the ability to cast Locate Object once by crushing it).

  • For Artur, Molock, and Francis: Three stones one silver, two gray remain in his palm. Though you did not enter, Strahd offers them with a mocking tilt of his head. "A pity to leave a wager unfinished. Take them. Consider them a dowry for the 'peace' you hope to find."

Strahd mounts Beucephalus, the Nightmareâ€™s hooves igniting with a sickly flame. He reaches into his heavy cloak and produces two final items, with a wave of his hand hovering gently in the air in front of him.

Strahd points to the hovering item:Â 
â€œIt is said that the god who died here, though its name is lost to time, left several relics behind. This is one of them.Â I give to you without let or lienÂ The Twilight Crest."

He gestures to the second item; aÂ thick envelope sealed with black wax.

"My chamberlain has grown weary of searching for you in the mud of the woods," Strahd remarks. "I extend to you a formal invitation to dine at my table.Â  I expect your attendance at dusk on the night of the moon's last light, in 5 days' time Â My carriage will be waiting at theÂ crossroads of Ravenloft, beyond the western gate."

With a flare of his cloak and a crack of dry thunder, the Count and his steed vanish.

On Tue, Jan 13, 2026, 12:06â€¯PM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
You all watch as after Gregor stumble out ... Rachel steps in.

She is gone for barely more than a long breath, but as she emerges you see her eyes shining. Perhaps tears, or just the chill air of Barovia you cannot be certain.

Strahd watches you emerge, noting the emotion you display. He doesn't mock you as he did Gregor; instead, he looks at you with a strange, predatory curiosity.

"You carry the scent of a peaceful hearth, little artist. Most who enter the Wall see power or gold; you saw a home that no longer exists. A dangerous thing, to be anchored by love in a place that feeds on grief. I wonder... will that anchor keep you steady, or will it be the weight that finally pulls you under?"

On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 4:07â€¯PM Edward Baird <edward.r.baird@gmail.com> wrote:
Gregor staggers out of the mist... drunk?

And bleeding. Definitely bleeding; the stuff racing down his nose like a contest to escape whatever lies within.

He staggers uncontrollably, capers like a madman, cleaves his arms tightly to his chest with tears streaming down his face. something halfway between a sob and a cheer ripping from his throat as he stumbles to the ground before the party, kicking and agouging in the mud and the blood and the beer. Beer?

He jerks suddenly upright, still on his knees, blood and mud whipping away as he straightens ramrod; wild eyes locking fixedly on Morlock,Â 

His mouth opens, at first a squeek... then a roar, "YOU!!!!"

"ASK ME THE SECRET OF THE WEAVE OF MAKING GOODBERRY JUICE!!!!!"


On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 9:52â€¯AM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:

He is gone for only a few seconds. He lunges out of the fog, tumbling into the mud of Yester Hill with his arms wrapped tightly around... nothing.

His nose is bleeding slowly, and can't be staunched. (It will leak slowly for the next 1 hour of in game time)

Strahd watches Gregor tumble into the mud, clutching at the air.Â  He lets out a short, sharp bark of genuine amusement.

"A thief to the last, Sir Gregor? You tried to carry the sun out in a bucket. Many have tried to loot the Wall; few have the spirit to actually try and wrestle a god's memory into the mud. I admire the audacity, if not the results."

On Sat, Jan 10, 2026 at 7:09â€¯AM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:

The air at the foot of Yester Hill is different. The scent of pine and ozone from the ritual has been replaced by a cloying, silver dampness that tastes of old copper and ancient dust. Ahead of you, the world simply... ends.

A shadowed wall of impenetrable fog looms above the earth here, stretching forth to meet the heavens far above. It is not a mist that moves with the wind; it is a solid, silent presence. As you stand before it, strange shapes and silhouettes drift through its depthsâ€”ghosts of things that never wereâ€”and distant voices whisper just out of earshot, calling your names in a language you almost understand.

Standing thirty feet away from his nightmare, Beucephalus, Strahd von Zarovich rises from a kneeling position as you approach. He pockets something small and luminescent within his cloak, a thin smile playing on his lips.

"Congratulations," he says, his voice cutting through the damp silence. "You played my little game with surprising competence. I trust Ludmilla's humiliation will serve as a lasting lesson for her."

He gestures to the towering bank of fog behind him.

"The ancestors of the Forest Folk believed this to be the corpse of an ancient god, whose last exhalation of divinity produced this mist. They called it the Whispering Wall. It is said that for those with the courage to enter as pilgrims, the Wall offers a vision of one's deepest desires."

He pauses, his eyes reflecting the silver gray of the mist.

"It is a powerful thing, to know oneself and one's desires. And yet dangerous, as well. I have walked its depths myself. I have seen the white fortress of my youth, the bells of my home ringing through the fog. It is... enticing."

Strahd offers you a final challenge before he grants you the rewards of your victory:

  1. The Pilgrimage: You must step into the Wall and face what you truly want. Strahd promises not to look; your desires are yours alone.

  2. The Risk: Many become lost, too entranced by the illusions to ever leave.

  3. The Choice: To return, you must leave under your own power. The way back comes but once.

  4. The Reward: Those who return safely will receive a "shard of the power of the Wall itself."

He watches you now, a taunting glint in his eye, waiting to see if you have the strength of will to face yourselves, or if you are merely "lesser men" doomed to trade your lives for dreams.

A simple question for each of you... Do you step into the mist?

Remember his warning:Â The way back comes but once.

You all watch as after Gregor stumble out ... Rachel steps in.

She is gone for barely more than a long breath, but as she emerges you see her eyes shining. Perhaps tears, or just the chill air of Barovia you cannot be certain.

Strahd watches you emerge, noting the emotion you display. He doesn't mock you as he did Gregor; instead, he looks at you with a strange, predatory curiosity.

"You carry the scent of a peaceful hearth, little artist. Most who enter the Wall see power or gold; you saw a home that no longer exists. A dangerous thing, to be anchored by love in a place that feeds on grief. I wonder... will that anchor keep you steady, or will it be the weight that finally pulls you under?"



On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 11:05â€¯AM Edward Baird <edward.r.baird@gmail.com> wrote:
And so very much much more.

The best Tea Time ever.Â 

Â I very much thought that Francis and his one paladin level was now the defactoÂ and dejure healer :PÂ 

On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 10:21â€¯AM Roland Zeuge <roland.zeuge@gmail.com> wrote:
Gregor went into the mist and met Talnar and Drethor?Â  Who then sat down with him for tea with a werewolf?

On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 4:07â€¯PM Edward Baird <edward.r.baird@gmail.com> wrote:
Gregor staggers out of the mist... drunk?

And bleeding. Definitely bleeding; the stuff racing down his nose like a contest to escape whatever lies within.

He staggers uncontrollably, capers like a madman, cleaves his arms tightly to his chest with tears streaming down his face. something halfway between a sob and a cheer ripping from his throat as he stumbles to the ground before the party, kicking and agouging in the mud and the blood and the beer. Beer?

He jerks suddenly upright, still on his knees, blood and mud whipping away as he straightens ramrod; wild eyes locking fixedly on Morlock,Â 

His mouth opens, at first a squeek... then a roar, "YOU!!!!"

"ASK ME THE SECRET OF THE WEAVE OF MAKING GOODBERRY JUICE!!!!!"


On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 9:52â€¯AM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
You all watch as Gregor shuffles toward the wall, somehow faster or more driven toward it than anyone else in the party. (or the first to write an email response, who knows!?)

He is gone for only a few seconds. He lunges out of the fog, tumbling into the mud of Yester Hill with his arms wrapped tightly around... nothing.

His nose is bleeding slowly, and can't be staunched. (It will leak slowly for the next 1 hour of in game time)

Strahd watches Gregor tumble into the mud, clutching at the air.Â  He lets out a short, sharp bark of genuine amusement.

"A thief to the last, Sir Gregor? You tried to carry the sun out in a bucket. Many have tried to loot the Wall; few have the spirit to actually try and wrestle a god's memory into the mud. I admire the audacity, if not the results."

On Sat, Jan 10, 2026, 3:04â€¯AM Edward Baird <edward.r.baird@gmail.com> wrote:

â€œLetâ€™s see. a Towering White wall of mist; White wall of mist blasting up into the heavens and beyond; held within is the risk of becoming Lost, stuck for generations in search of knowledge and power and Dreaming of escape?Â  And for that small inconvenience, I get to keepâ€¦ an evaporating shard of mist,â€Â

â€œWerewolvesâ€™ll no doubt be within too if thereâ€™s an impenetrable castle. Next youâ€™ll probably be promising me the opportunity to sit down for a tea party with the Fair Folk, along with lions, tigers, dragons and bloody scarecrows.â€


The toothy grin flashes wider still, â€œI do like tea. You shouldnâ€™t threaten me such a good time /and/ a meal! Of course Iâ€™m in!!â€


â€œBesides, I can hardly turn down an invitation, nor not be Accepted after a speech like that. You just said yourself thereâ€™s probably no way to be out.â€


The old man glances Skyward, begins to relieve himself of his clothes, before suddenlyÂ  stopping with a glanceÂ  at the others


An awkward cough later, Gregor plucks a loose thread his cloak, tossing the white thread aside into the grass and straightens his belt, mutters more to himself than the others, â€œerr, right. Leaving most of the clothes on.. I suppose..â€Â 


He glances about the party a final time, andÂ  immediately Harrumphs at them, â€œJust you wait and watch my greatest desire turn out to be purifying some witch at the stake when itâ€™s all said and done. Ahh well, Best head to it then ; I doubt I could weave in any more shite this evening if I tried!.â€


Gregor takes up his cane to prepare to enter the mists, harrumphing obnoxiously at the others all the while.

On Sat, Jan 10, 2026 at 1:42â€¯AM Roland Zeuge <roland.zeuge@gmail.com> wrote:

On Sat, Jan 10, 2026 at 7:09â€¯AM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:

The air at the foot of Yester Hill is different. The scent of pine and ozone from the ritual has been replaced by a cloying, silver dampness that tastes of old copper and ancient dust. Ahead of you, the world simply... ends.

A shadowed wall of impenetrable fog looms above the earth here, stretching forth to meet the heavens far above. It is not a mist that moves with the wind; it is a solid, silent presence. As you stand before it, strange shapes and silhouettes drift through its depthsâ€”ghosts of things that never wereâ€”and distant voices whisper just out of earshot, calling your names in a language you almost understand.

Standing thirty feet away from his nightmare, Beucephalus, Strahd von Zarovich rises from a kneeling position as you approach. He pockets something small and luminescent within his cloak, a thin smile playing on his lips.

"Congratulations," he says, his voice cutting through the damp silence. "You played my little game with surprising competence. I trust Ludmilla's humiliation will serve as a lasting lesson for her."

He gestures to the towering bank of fog behind him.

"The ancestors of the Forest Folk believed this to be the corpse of an ancient god, whose last exhalation of divinity produced this mist. They called it the Whispering Wall. It is said that for those with the courage to enter as pilgrims, the Wall offers a vision of one's deepest desires."

He pauses, his eyes reflecting the silver gray of the mist.

"It is a powerful thing, to know oneself and one's desires. And yet dangerous, as well. I have walked its depths myself. I have seen the white fortress of my youth, the bells of my home ringing through the fog. It is... enticing."

Strahd offers you a final challenge before he grants you the rewards of your victory:

  1. The Pilgrimage: You must step into the Wall and face what you truly want. Strahd promises not to look; your desires are yours alone.

  2. The Risk: Many become lost, too entranced by the illusions to ever leave.

  3. The Choice: To return, you must leave under your own power. The way back comes but once.

  4. The Reward: Those who return safely will receive a "shard of the power of the Wall itself."

He watches you now, a taunting glint in his eye, waiting to see if you have the strength of will to face yourselves, or if you are merely "lesser men" doomed to trade your lives for dreams.

A simple question for each of you... Do you step into the mist?

Remember his warning:Â The way back comes but once.

On Sun, Jan 18, 2026 at 10:12â€¯PM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
As Gregor and Rachel areÂ catching their breath after their brush with the "Dead Godâ€™s exhalation," Strahd von Zarovich steps forward. He does not offer a hand to help them. Instead, he looks at them with the cold, clinical interest of a scientist watching insects in a jar.

Strahd produces a small, luminescent spark from his cloakâ€”a glede, pulsing with an inner heat. As he holds it toward the Wall, the fog seems to curl in on itself extending tendrils of wisping misting laced with lightning.

With the sound of cracking ice, the vapor hardens. Strahd opens his palm to reveal four small gemstones, no larger than a fingernail.

  • For Rachel: A Silver Gemstone. It feels oddly warm, smelling faintly of cinnamon and old wood. (Grants the ability to cast Misty Step once by crushing it).

  • For Gregor: A Gray Gemstone. It pulses with a frantic, violet light, as if trying to recall the infinite library it was stolen from. (Grants the ability to cast Locate Object once by crushing it).

  • For Artur, Molock, and Francis: Three stones one silver, two gray remain in his palm. Though you did not enter, Strahd offers them with a mocking tilt of his head. "A pity to leave a wager unfinished. Take them. Consider them a dowry for the 'peace' you hope to find."

Strahd mounts Beucephalus, the Nightmareâ€™s hooves igniting with a sickly flame. He reaches into his heavy cloak and produces two final items, with a wave of his hand hovering gently in the air in front of him.

Strahd points to the hovering item:Â 
â€œIt is said that the god who died here, though its name is lost to time, left several relics behind. This is one of them.Â I give to you without let or lienÂ The Twilight Crest."

He gestures to the second item; aÂ thick envelope sealed with black wax.

"My chamberlain has grown weary of searching for you in the mud of the woods," Strahd remarks. "I extend to you a formal invitation to dine at my table.Â  I expect your attendance at dusk on the night of the moon's last light, in 5 days' time Â My carriage will be waiting at theÂ crossroads of Ravenloft, beyond the western gate."

With a flare of his cloak and a crack of dry thunder, the Count and his steed vanish.

I honor my word to the letter, as I expect of all in my domain."

On Sat, Jan 10, 2026 at 7:09â€¯AM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:

The air at the foot of Yester Hill is different. The scent of pine and ozone from the ritual has been replaced by a cloying, silver dampness that tastes of old copper and ancient dust. Ahead of you, the world simply... ends.

A shadowed wall of impenetrable fog looms above the earth here, stretching forth to meet the heavens far above. It is not a mist that moves with the wind; it is a solid, silent presence. As you stand before it, strange shapes and silhouettes drift through its depthsâ€”ghosts of things that never wereâ€”and distant voices whisper just out of earshot, calling your names in a language you almost understand.

Standing thirty feet away from his nightmare, Beucephalus, Strahd von Zarovich rises from a kneeling position as you approach. He pockets something small and luminescent within his cloak, a thin smile playing on his lips.

"Congratulations," he says, his voice cutting through the damp silence. "You played my little game with surprising competence. I trust Ludmilla's humiliation will serve as a lasting lesson for her."

He gestures to the towering bank of fog behind him.

"The ancestors of the Forest Folk believed this to be the corpse of an ancient god, whose last exhalation of divinity produced this mist. They called it the Whispering Wall. It is said that for those with the courage to enter as pilgrims, the Wall offers a vision of one's deepest desires."

He pauses, his eyes reflecting the silver gray of the mist.

"It is a powerful thing, to know oneself and one's desires. And yet dangerous, as well. I have walked its depths myself. I have seen the white fortress of my youth, the bells of my home ringing through the fog. It is... enticing."

Strahd offers you a final challenge before he grants you the rewards of your victory:

  1. The Pilgrimage: You must step into the Wall and face what you truly want. Strahd promises not to look; your desires are yours alone.

  2. The Risk: Many become lost, too entranced by the illusions to ever leave.

  3. The Choice: To return, you must leave under your own power. The way back comes but once.

  4. The Reward: Those who return safely will receive a "shard of the power of the Wall itself."

He watches you now, a taunting glint in his eye, waiting to see if you have the strength of will to face yourselves, or if you are merely "lesser men" doomed to trade your lives for dreams.

A simple question for each of you... Do you step into the mist?

Strahd points to the hovering item:Â 
â€œIt is said that the god who died here, though its name is lost to time, left several relics behind. This is one of them.Â I give to you without let or lienÂ The Twilight Crest."

He gestures to the second item; aÂ thick envelope sealed with black wax.

"My chamberlain has grown weary of searching for you in the mud of the woods," Strahd remarks. "I extend to you a formal invitation to dine at my table.Â  I expect your attendance at dusk on the night of the moon's last light, in 5 days' time Â My carriage will be waiting at theÂ crossroads of Ravenloft, beyond the western gate."

With a flare of his cloak and a crack of dry thunder, the Count and his steed vanish.

On Tue, Jan 13, 2026, 12:06â€¯PM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
You all watch as after Gregor stumble out ... Rachel steps in.

She is gone for barely more than a long breath, but as she emerges you see her eyes shining. Perhaps tears, or just the chill air of Barovia you cannot be certain.

Strahd watches you emerge, noting the emotion you display. He doesn't mock you as he did Gregor; instead, he looks at you with a strange, predatory curiosity.

"You carry the scent of a peaceful hearth, little artist. Most who enter the Wall see power or gold; you saw a home that no longer exists. A dangerous thing, to be anchored by love in a place that feeds on grief. I wonder... will that anchor keep you steady, or will it be the weight that finally pulls you under?"

On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 9:52â€¯AM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:

He is gone for only a few seconds. He lunges out of the fog, tumbling into the mud of Yester Hill with his arms wrapped tightly around... nothing.

His nose is bleeding slowly, and can't be staunched. (It will leak slowly for the next 1 hour of in game time)

Strahd watches Gregor tumble into the mud, clutching at the air.Â  He lets out a short, sharp bark of genuine amusement.

"A thief to the last, Sir Gregor? You tried to carry the sun out in a bucket. Many have tried to loot the Wall; few have the spirit to actually try and wrestle a god's memory into the mud. I admire the audacity, if not the results."

On Sat, Jan 10, 2026 at 7:09â€¯AM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:

The air at the foot of Yester Hill is different. The scent of pine and ozone from the ritual has been replaced by a cloying, silver dampness that tastes of old copper and ancient dust. Ahead of you, the world simply... ends.

A shadowed wall of impenetrable fog looms above the earth here, stretching forth to meet the heavens far above. It is not a mist that moves with the wind; it is a solid, silent presence. As you stand before it, strange shapes and silhouettes drift through its depthsâ€”ghosts of things that never wereâ€”and distant voices whisper just out of earshot, calling your names in a language you almost understand.

Standing thirty feet away from his nightmare, Beucephalus, Strahd von Zarovich rises from a kneeling position as you approach. He pockets something small and luminescent within his cloak, a thin smile playing on his lips.

"Congratulations," he says, his voice cutting through the damp silence. "You played my little game with surprising competence. I trust Ludmilla's humiliation will serve as a lasting lesson for her."

He gestures to the towering bank of fog behind him.

"The ancestors of the Forest Folk believed this to be the corpse of an ancient god, whose last exhalation of divinity produced this mist. They called it the Whispering Wall. It is said that for those with the courage to enter as pilgrims, the Wall offers a vision of one's deepest desires."

He pauses, his eyes reflecting the silver gray of the mist.

"It is a powerful thing, to know oneself and one's desires. And yet dangerous, as well. I have walked its depths myself. I have seen the white fortress of my youth, the bells of my home ringing through the fog. It is... enticing."

Strahd offers you a final challenge before he grants you the rewards of your victory:

  1. The Pilgrimage: You must step into the Wall and face what you truly want. Strahd promises not to look; your desires are yours alone.

  2. The Risk: Many become lost, too entranced by the illusions to ever leave.

  3. The Choice: To return, you must leave under your own power. The way back comes but once.

  4. The Reward: Those who return safely will receive a "shard of the power of the Wall itself."

He watches you now, a taunting glint in his eye, waiting to see if you have the strength of will to face yourselves, or if you are merely "lesser men" doomed to trade your lives for dreams.

A simple question for each of you... Do you step into the mist?

Remember his warning:Â The way back comes but once.

On Sun, Jan 18, 2026 at 10:12â€¯PM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
As Gregor and Rachel areÂ catching their breath after their brush with the "Dead Godâ€™s exhalation," Strahd von Zarovich steps forward. He does not offer a hand to help them. Instead, he looks at them with the cold, clinical interest of a scientist watching insects in a jar.

Strahd produces a small, luminescent spark from his cloakâ€”a glede, pulsing with an inner heat. As he holds it toward the Wall, the fog seems to curl in on itself extending tendrils of wisping misting laced with lightning.

With the sound of cracking ice, the vapor hardens. Strahd opens his palm to reveal four small gemstones, no larger than a fingernail.

  • For Rachel: A Silver Gemstone. It feels oddly warm, smelling faintly of cinnamon and old wood. (Grants the ability to cast Misty Step once by crushing it).

  • For Gregor: A Gray Gemstone. It pulses with a frantic, violet light, as if trying to recall the infinite library it was stolen from. (Grants the ability to cast Locate Object once by crushing it).

  • For Artur, Molock, and Francis: Three stones one silver, two gray remain in his palm. Though you did not enter, Strahd offers them with a mocking tilt of his head. "A pity to leave a wager unfinished. Take them. Consider them a dowry for the 'peace' you hope to find."

Strahd mounts Beucephalus, the Nightmareâ€™s hooves igniting with a sickly flame. He reaches into his heavy cloak and produces two final items, with a wave of his hand hovering gently in the air in front of him.

Strahd points to the hovering item:Â 
â€œIt is said that the god who died here, though its name is lost to time, left several relics behind. This is one of them.Â I give to you without let or lienÂ The Twilight Crest."

He gestures to the second item; aÂ thick envelope sealed with black wax.

"My chamberlain has grown weary of searching for you in the mud of the woods," Strahd remarks. "I extend to you a formal invitation to dine at my table.Â  I expect your attendance at dusk on the night of the moon's last light, in 5 days' time Â My carriage will be waiting at theÂ crossroads of Ravenloft, beyond the western gate."

With a flare of his cloak and a crack of dry thunder, the Count and his steed vanish.

On Sat, Jan 10, 2026 at 7:09â€¯AM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:

The air at the foot of Yester Hill is different. The scent of pine and ozone from the ritual has been replaced by a cloying, silver dampness that tastes of old copper and ancient dust. Ahead of you, the world simply... ends.

A shadowed wall of impenetrable fog looms above the earth here, stretching forth to meet the heavens far above. It is not a mist that moves with the wind; it is a solid, silent presence. As you stand before it, strange shapes and silhouettes drift through its depthsâ€”ghosts of things that never wereâ€”and distant voices whisper just out of earshot, calling your names in a language you almost understand.

Standing thirty feet away from his nightmare, Beucephalus, Strahd von Zarovich rises from a kneeling position as you approach. He pockets something small and luminescent within his cloak, a thin smile playing on his lips.

"Congratulations," he says, his voice cutting through the damp silence. "You played my little game with surprising competence. I trust Ludmilla's humiliation will serve as a lasting lesson for her."

He gestures to the towering bank of fog behind him.

"The ancestors of the Forest Folk believed this to be the corpse of an ancient god, whose last exhalation of divinity produced this mist. They called it the Whispering Wall. It is said that for those with the courage to enter as pilgrims, the Wall offers a vision of one's deepest desires."

He pauses, his eyes reflecting the silver gray of the mist.

"It is a powerful thing, to know oneself and one's desires. And yet dangerous, as well. I have walked its depths myself. I have seen the white fortress of my youth, the bells of my home ringing through the fog. It is... enticing."

Strahd offers you a final challenge before he grants you the rewards of your victory:

  1. The Pilgrimage: You must step into the Wall and face what you truly want. Strahd promises not to look; your desires are yours alone.

  2. The Risk: Many become lost, too entranced by the illusions to ever leave.

  3. The Choice: To return, you must leave under your own power. The way back comes but once.

  4. The Reward: Those who return safely will receive a "shard of the power of the Wall itself."

He watches you now, a taunting glint in his eye, waiting to see if you have the strength of will to face yourselves, or if you are merely "lesser men" doomed to trade your lives for dreams.

A simple question for each of you... Do you step into the mist?

Remember his warning:Â The way back comes but once.

On Sun, Jan 18, 2026 at 10:12â€¯PM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
As Gregor and Rachel areÂ catching their breath after their brush with the "Dead Godâ€™s exhalation," Strahd von Zarovich steps forward. He does not offer a hand to help them. Instead, he looks at them with the cold, clinical interest of a scientist watching insects in a jar.

Strahd produces a small, luminescent spark from his cloakâ€”a glede, pulsing with an inner heat. As he holds it toward the Wall, the fog seems to curl in on itself extending tendrils of wisping misting laced with lightning.

With the sound of cracking ice, the vapor hardens. Strahd opens his palm to reveal four small gemstones, no larger than a fingernail.

  • For Rachel: A Silver Gemstone. It feels oddly warm, smelling faintly of cinnamon and old wood. (Grants the ability to cast Misty Step once by crushing it).

  • For Gregor: A Gray Gemstone. It pulses with a frantic, violet light, as if trying to recall the infinite library it was stolen from. (Grants the ability to cast Locate Object once by crushing it).

  • For Artur, Molock, and Francis: Three stones one silver, two gray remain in his palm. Though you did not enter, Strahd offers them with a mocking tilt of his head. "A pity to leave a wager unfinished. Take them. Consider them a dowry for the 'peace' you hope to find."

Strahd mounts Beucephalus, the Nightmareâ€™s hooves igniting with a sickly flame. He reaches into his heavy cloak and produces two final items, with a wave of his hand hovering gently in the air in front of him.

Strahd points to the hovering item:Â 
â€œIt is said that the god who died here, though its name is lost to time, left several relics behind. This is one of them.Â I give to you without let or lienÂ The Twilight Crest."

He gestures to the second item; aÂ thick envelope sealed with black wax.

"My chamberlain has grown weary of searching for you in the mud of the woods," Strahd remarks. "I extend to you a formal invitation to dine at my table.Â  I expect your attendance at dusk on the night of the moon's last light, in 5 days' time Â My carriage will be waiting at theÂ crossroads of Ravenloft, beyond the western gate."

With a flare of his cloak and a crack of dry thunder, the Count and his steed vanish.

On Tue, Jan 13, 2026, 12:06â€¯PM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
You all watch as after Gregor stumble out ... Rachel steps in.

She is gone for barely more than a long breath, but as she emerges you see her eyes shining. Perhaps tears, or just the chill air of Barovia you cannot be certain.

Strahd watches you emerge, noting the emotion you display. He doesn't mock you as he did Gregor; instead, he looks at you with a strange, predatory curiosity.

"You carry the scent of a peaceful hearth, little artist. Most who enter the Wall see power or gold; you saw a home that no longer exists. A dangerous thing, to be anchored by love in a place that feeds on grief. I wonder... will that anchor keep you steady, or will it be the weight that finally pulls you under?"

On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 4:07â€¯PM Edward Baird <edward.r.baird@gmail.com> wrote:
Gregor staggers out of the mist... drunk?

And bleeding. Definitely bleeding; the stuff racing down his nose like a contest to escape whatever lies within.

He staggers uncontrollably, capers like a madman, cleaves his arms tightly to his chest with tears streaming down his face. something halfway between a sob and a cheer ripping from his throat as he stumbles to the ground before the party, kicking and agouging in the mud and the blood and the beer. Beer?

He jerks suddenly upright, still on his knees, blood and mud whipping away as he straightens ramrod; wild eyes locking fixedly on Morlock,Â 

His mouth opens, at first a squeek... then a roar, "YOU!!!!"

"ASK ME THE SECRET OF THE WEAVE OF MAKING GOODBERRY JUICE!!!!!"


On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 9:52â€¯AM Ben Jones <theonlyalterego@gmail.com> wrote:
You all watch as Gregor shuffles toward the wall, somehow faster or more driven toward it than anyone else in the party. (or the first to write an email response, who knows!?)

He is gone for only a few seconds. He lunges out of the fog, tumbling into the mud of Yester Hill with his arms wrapped tightly around... nothing.

His nose is bleeding slowly, and can't be staunched. (It will leak slowly for the next 1 hour of in game time)

Strahd watches Gregor tumble into the mud, clutching at the air.Â  He lets out a short, sharp bark of genuine amusement.

"A thief to the last, Sir Gregor? You tried to carry the sun out in a bucket. Many have tried to loot the Wall; few have the spirit to actually try and wrestle a god's memory into the mud. I admire the audacity, if not the results."
